title: A Question of Temperature
label: Yep Roc
description: Former dB's frontman is backed by Yo La Tengo on this repackaged and retitled version of their limited October '04 get-out-the-vote effort.

title: LCD Soundsystem
label: DFA
description: With two epochal singles and some of the decade's most engaging production and remix work under his belt, the DFA's James Murphy unveils his full-length debut with LCD Soundsystem. Also included on a bonus disc are-- at last-- his seven previously released A- and B-sides.

title: Starship Galactica
description: 19-year-old Ryan Kidwell suffers from a textbook Jekyll-and-Hyde complex. By day, mild-mannered Mr Kidwell leads a typical adolescent lifestyle, attending ...

title: Burn the Maps
label: Anti-
description: Irish rockers' latest for Anti continues their tradition of blending trad-rock and bombast.

title: Peanut Butter and Jelly Live at the Ginger Minge
label: Narnack
description: San Francsico indie rockers are more than eye-catching album art.

title: The Bodyshop
label: Important
description: Elusive Dutch duo continues to add beats and guitars to its opaque post-industrial ambient dronescapes.

title: Constant Lover EP
label: Paper Bag
description: Paper Bag trio delivers efficient, high-tempo indie pop thrills.

title: PREfection
label: 4AD
description: Singer/songwriters seem like a solitary bunch. Flying solo, these artists are thrust into the spotlight alone, where each lyric ...

title: Where the Humans Eat
label: Team Love
description: Conor Oberst's Team Love imprint presents the debut LP from this 19-year-old singer-songwriter.

title: We Should Have Never Lived Like We Were Skyscrapers
label: Flameshovel
description: Determined Chicago indie rockers issue a promising debut.

title: Trials & Errors
label: Secretly Canadian
description: The first official release from the Jason Molina-led four-piece Magnolia Electric Co. is appropriately titled: It's a live album that finds his new group working out the kinks-- and aping Crazy Horse.

title: Superwolf
label: Drag City
description: A collaboration between Will Oldham and his longtime pal, former Chavez and Zwan guitarist Matt Sweeney.

title: Negrophilia
label: Thirsty Ear
description: Mike Ladd's contribution to Thirsty Ear's Blue Series takes its title from and is inspired by the writings of Petrine Archer-Straw.

title: Thieves EP
label: Misra
description: The Okkervil River principals issue their latest collection of haunted, folksy, story-oriented rock.

title: Notorious Lightning and Other Works EP
label: Merge
description: Daniel Bejar reworks a half-dozen Your Blues tracks with help from Frog Eyes guitarist and vocalist Carey Mercer.

title: I Sold Gold
label: Barsuk
description: Barsuk's other "O.C."-approved band offers up another round of their fractured push-button pop.

title: A Way of Life
label: Wax Trax!
description: Released more than 10 years after their debut, Suicide's third LP is often cruelly overlooked. A recent Mute reissue aims to redeem its reputation.

title: Purple Haze
label: Roc-A-Fella
description: Backed by beats ranging from wistful chipmunk soul to oppressive, bell-rattling NWA jacks and hypnotic electro bounce, Cam'ron bids adieu to Roc-A-Fella.

title: Before the Dawn Heals Us
label: Mute
description: Saying "au revoir" to longtime friend and collaborator Nicolas Fromageau, Anthony Gonzalez goes it alone for M83's third LP, a mammoth collusion of synth gasps and distorted swirls that's darker and more urban than its meadow-bound predecessor, Dead Cities, Red Seas & Lost Ghosts.

title: The Great Destroyer
label: Sub Pop
description: For their Dave Fridmann-produced Sub Pop debut, veteran slowcore band Low expand their palette, but achieve varying degrees of success.

title: Emoh
label: Merge
description: After years of mostly solo projects, the indie legend releases his first LP under his own name.

title: Eveningland
label: Rounder
description: Hem's cinematic and frequently gorgeous countrypolitan sound was nearly lost in the post-Dreamworks shuffle.

title: So Jealous
label: Vapor
description: Canadian indie pop twins trade in power chords and 80s retro.

title: Naturally
label: Daptone
description: Neo-soul's coffeeshop world gets a blast of deep funk grooves.

title: Worlds Apart
artist: ...And You Will Know Us by the Trail of Dead
label: Interscope
description: Austin-based rock heroes And You Will Know Us By the Trail of Dead follow the glorious noise and epic urgency of Source Tags & Codes with this sadly pompous, overreaching monstrosity.

title: All Harm Ends Here
label: Secretly Canadian
description: Secretly Canadian slowcore group Early Day Miners rise and occasionally shine on their fourth album.

title: This Right Here Is Buck 65
label: V2
description: Buck 65-- the Tom Waits of indie hip-hop-- makes his V2 debut.

title: Volume One: unIndian songs
label: Anticon
description: Anticon's Pedestrian conflates the histories of hip-hop and social violence on this strange, fractured record.

title: Before the Poison
label: Anti-
description: The legendary singer's new set of grim, gothic songs features collaborations with PJ Harvey, Nick Cave, Jon Brion, and Blur frontman Damon Albarn, among others.

title: Gemstones
label: Rough Trade
description: The former Moldy Peach is back with another platter of anti-folk bathroom humor.

title: Outside Closer
label: Domino
description: England's Hood-- who create dense, echoing arrangements that are reminiscent of the drifting sound-paintings of Bark Psychosis, Disco Inferno, or late-period Slowdive-- unveil their first LP of new music since 2001's Cold House.

title: Beauty and the Beat
label: IRS
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit the debut album by the Go-Go’s, a ’70s punk band that beat the odds to become ’80s pop superstars.

title: Vagabon
label: Nonesuch
description: On her self-titled sophomore effort, Laetitia Tamko leaps with both feet into new sounds and new horizons.

title: Pang
label: Perpetual Novice
description: The former Chairlift singer-songwriter centers her sweeping solo debut on her powerful voice, crafting love songs about the moment of surrender, the pain preceding it, and the euphoria after.

title: Heavy Lifter
label: Double Double Whammy
description: The duo’s third album is a nostalgic indie-pop rumination on suburban teenhood that thrums with hopeful energy. The best songs are like dispatches from a cracking cocoon.

title: No Holiday
label: Omnivore
description: The final album from the punk trio captures everything that was bratty, tender, and unforgettable about its leading force, Kim Shattuck, who passed away earlier this year.

title: Screamer
label: Mega Collider
description: On the band’s sixth album, frontman Stephan Jenkins Peter Pans his way through an improbably infectious set of would-be hits.

title: Dawn Chorus
label: LuckyMe
description: Pushing beyond his customary dancefloor focus, the French-Canadian producer twists club influences and collaborative input into a textured, exploratory sound, both intimate and immense.

title: As If It Were Forever
label: Alpha Pup
description: The idiosyncratic singer mixes R&B, ambient, and acoustic soul on her most accessible and fully-formed record, one that still feels like an open mic.

title: Singles Too
label: Don Giovanni
description: One of indie rock’s more consistent guitar bands charts its evolution with a career-spanning collection of non-album singles, B-sides, and cover songs.

label: Weird World
description: On his dense but meticulously rendered new album, the British folk singer uses grander pop arrangements to wade into the barbarism of modern life.

title: Metal Galaxy
label: Cooking Vinyl
description: After fusing J-Pop and heavy metal to great fanfare, the duo recruit international guests to expand their sound into even more unlikely hybrids.

title: Neighborhoods
label: Freedom to Spend
description: A newly reissued private-press curio from 1974 captures the bygone sounds of daily life in Portland, Oregon, in dreamy, proto-ambient form.

title: Broken
label: self-released
description: The prolific Maryland rapper is alternately serious, silly, and soulful.

title: True Love
label: You Are Accepted
description: With his intense baritone voice, Devon Welsh travels deep into the feelings of isolation and introspection with grace and beauty.

title: Blood Dust
label: self-released
description: Malcom Lacey’s long-running electro-acoustic project feels like a window into someone’s private world.

title: The Ra(w) Material
label: self-released
description: Two figures of underground rap—Philly’s Sadhugold and Virginia’s Ohbliv—team up for a politically blunted, cult rap record in the making.

title: Let the Sun Talk
label: self-released
description: The latest tape from the 20-year-old rapper is dense and mystic. MAVI delivers revelations from the shadows, concealed and mysterious, in search of fresh air and sunlight.

title: FLY or DIE II: bird dogs of paradise
label: International Anthem
description: The New York trumpeter and bandleader’s second album is darker, denser, and more experimental than its predecessor, but no less resonant.

title: No Home Record
label: Matador
description: After 38 years of making music, Kim Gordon’s thrilling solo debut lives at the vanguard of sound and performance, shot through with the beautiful, unsparing noise that has always defined her art.

title: True 2 Myself
label: Columbia
description: The breakout NY rapper’s emotionally affecting, piano-heavy street tales start to run together at 17 tracks.

title: My Star
label: Trouble in Mind
description: Chicago’s least-relaxed band doubles their personnel and scales up their sound for a set of unnerving new wave.

title: For Your Pleasure
label: Island
description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today, we revisit Bryan Ferry and Brian Eno’s glam-rock, art-school masterpiece.

title: Closer to Grey
label: Italians Do It Better
description: Chromatics set their surprise “seventh” album at the witching hour, telling a sometimes-muddled tale of heartbroken lovers reaching out to the spirit realm.

title: Movimiento Para Cambio
label: Pan
description: Velvety, ’90s-inspired deep house and industrial-punk sing-shouting make for a surprisingly complementary contrast.

title: Sonic Citadel
label: Thrill Jockey
description: The noise duo’s seventh album is the most life-affirming and accessible music they’ve ever made.

title: Two Hands
label: 4AD
description: The second landmark album this year from Big Thief is raw, tactile, and essential. The intimate songs zoom in on a band that feels, at this moment, totally invincible.

title: Odds Against Tomorrow
label: Palilalia
description: Stepping away from the overt historicism of previous recordings, the guitarist opts for a subtler—but just as expressive—investigation of folk and blues.

title: Terror Management
label: Backwoodz Studioz
description: On his bleak new album, woods doubles down on the misery that snakes through all his music.

title: On a Clear Day I Can See You Forever
label: Smalltown Supersound
description: The Scandinavian synthesizer maven pays dusts off dozens of arcane vintage machines in an all-hardware studio recording meant to summon the spirit of bygone circuitry.

title: Hello Exile
label: Epitaph
description: What does it mean to get older in punk? Were the good old days ever that good? Though the titles change, the Pennsylvania band’s song remains the same.

title: Old LP
label: UME
description: The ’90s alt-rockers’ first new album in more than 20 years has the vibe of a beloved record that was, for whatever reason, sitting on a shelf.

title: Tell All Your Friends
label: Craft
description: The newly reissued landmark debut from the Amityville emo band takes heartbreak, jealousy, and depression to an operatic intensity, but does so with sharp wit, a knowing wink, and oh so many hooks.

title: Signal
label: Stones Throw
description: The trio’s debut is an exercise in post-punk and no-wave galvanism crafted from throbbing bass, tight-zipped drumbeats, and buzzing synths.

title: Over It
label: Interscope
description: The 23-year-old Atlanta singer’s slow-groove R&B plays out like a telenovela, feeling irresistibly fresh, messy, and human.

title: Ghosteen
label: Ghosteen Ltd
description: Forty years into his career, Nick Cave emerges with one of his most powerful albums yet, an endlessly giving and complex meditation on mortality and our collective grief.

title: Fuck Yo Feelings
label: Loma Vista
description: Throwing open his studio doors, the pianist aims for a loose, mixtape-like vibe, but the stacked guest list yields a scattershot party that only ends up overstaying its own welcome.
